Write the abstract. It is only one page - how hard can it be? Write the abstract before you write the thesis, then again after, modifying it to agree with how the thesis turned out. A nice clear and positive abstract puts the marker into a good frame of mind, and will do the same for the writer. If you still have time and facilities to do research (whether experiments or literature study) then imagine you have finished them successfully and write the abstract for this great piece of work. Be punchy and positive. It does not matter that you do not know the result, just choose one. “It has been clearly shown that X causes Y, but only providing Z is present.” If you find out the opposite it is easy enough to change your abstract. If not, then imagine you have produced a thesis with a good clear critical review. What will it say? What are the main points? Write them down, and then produce the arguments which lead to them. When dealing with literature, the usual mistake is to find 100 papers and say weak things about them, usually not having actually read them completely. Try to find some key papers and show that you have understood them. Draw conclusions by comparison. “A first showed that Y appeared to be caused by X, which was independently confirmed by B. However, C stated that Z was the key factor, otherwise Y would not happen. D showed that W would not produce Y, but appears not to have considered X. In dealing with W, X and Z, E failed to report if Y occurred at all. In this project, the data of A,B,C,D, and E have been compared and correlated to determine a probable explanation.” When you have your abstract, make your chapter headings. Then make short notes of what goes into each chapter. By the miracle of the word processor, you can do these in any order. Make sure you have something in each of your chapters, then expand until you are close to the deadline. Finish a week before the deadline. This is the thesis you can had in at any point. Then read it and make improvements till a day before the deadline. Make sure you have independently backed up copies. (The plea that I lost my laptop is not acceptable.) If it is to be printed, print one version well before the deadline, and your final one at least the day before the deadline. Students trying to print on deadline day often leads to tears.

I’m answering in regards to the thesis statement, not the research paper written for a college degree. A simple trick I learned is to think of a thesis like a preview line for your essay. A thesis will tell your audience what the material is about. Educational systems will teach for it to be one to two sentences found at the end of the introduction paragraph. (This is not a concrete rule but generally is the least risky to pull off, especially in school.) You will make your claim or point that the rest of the essay will then proceed to reinforce. You are telling the reader “this is how I feel, and if you stopped reading now you would at least take away my main idea, but you should keep reading because I have some interesting points to prove.” Oftentimes a thesis will include main ideas from the rest of your supporting paragraphs, especially if the essay is shorter (like the traditional five paragraph essay found in the American public eduction system). If the essay is longer, then it should still try and include your main focal points without making the sentence(s) a convoluted mess. Since a thesis statement is like the directions on Google maps for the rest of your paper, writing one requires you to have a good idea of what your paper will be about, and what claim or topic you will be discussing. Generally, you will be ready to create a thesis after lengthy research and framing of your paper. This varies from person to person though. I actually write my essay and then go back over it and insert my thesis, making it the final part I add. The key to a good thesis i a good thesis statement. To generate a thesis statement you need to come up with general ideas form your topic of discussion that acts as sample thesis statements. From these sample thesis statements, you generate a general statement that covers all these general ideas by combining them to form a general idea. Revise your general statement to ensure it agrees with all the key factors stated below such as clarity and conciseness. The revised general statement thus becomes your thesis statement. For an efficient and concise thesis statement that has direction and can be evidenced by supporting points, ensure to; · Avoid the use of ambiguous words and rightfully place the statement The statement is best placed when written early in the paper. In addition, it should not include words such as “the main idea of my paper is…” · Provide a narrow and concise statement but broad enough for you to place an argument A general idea cannot be argued appropriately and in-depth as expected in a paper. A statement that is too narrow, however, leaves no room for development and explanation. Additionally, when showing a relation between two general ideas in a statement; use conjunctions that best explain the relation e.g. although, though, because among others. · Write a statement that is easily understood To write a perfectly good thesis statement you need to keep revising it and come up with a statement that is not only clear and easily understood but also allows the reader to be aware of your position based on the statement. The reader should also become aware of why your opinion on the issue matters. A statement should not announce the topic alone but should also express subjectivity. When expressing subjectivity, provide a good enough and valuable explanation. For example, instead of writing “loans, grants and donor funds are not the key to developing the poor”, one should write” making the poor aware of their capacity to be involved in their development will yield successful results”. Finally, avoid oversimplifying a concept or even merely stating a proven fact. Go deep with your idea · Express originality It is important to prove the worth of your paper. Your idea should not appear generic or formulated from other people’s ideas. When developing your thesis statement, you may formulate it from general ideas and arguments of others. You need to keep revising it nonetheless until it allows you to answer the question ‘so what’ without borrowing ideas of others or boring the reader in the process. Furthermore, it is common to experience a ‘thought block’ when developing your thesis statement. When this occurs, you are expected to brainstorm ideas on the topic. Write whatever comes to mind on the topic. From this point, you follow the steps to coming up with a good thesis statement. Ultimately, as a writer, you need to express flexibility while writing your thesis statement. Whether you are justifying a claim (persuasive), explaining a concept (expository) or evaluating an issue (analytical); the topic or general idea may change as the essay progresses. It is important to, therefore, change your thesis statement to suit your essay.

The moment you are asked to write a dissertation it indicates that you are almost nearing the end of a crucial stage of your education. Hence you must devote enough time to plan and structure your work as it is essential that you prepare well. Through observing the provided steps, you will be in a position to write a dissertation without challenges. Before you start writing Choose your Topic • You must carefully select a topic and ensure that it is engaging and meaningful. • In case you have difficulties finding a topic you can research your academic journals, course materials and newspapers to identify issues that relate to your field. • Also, consult your supervisor before settling on a topic to obtain the necessary advice. Understand the Requirements • Before you start to plan, familiarize yourself with all the recommendations, i.e. the faculty’s ethics, reference style guides, and structure of the dissertation to avoid making costly mistakes at the end. Plan • Set your goals and make a program that will help you to remain focused. • Ensure your ideas lead you to achieve your goals having in mind that your goals should be based on the way you are planning on carrying out your dissertation. Start Writing • Aim to write a certain number of words each week to be productive and to avoid last minute rush. • As you write, you will have a better understanding of your topic, and your emphasis will change. • Question yourself as you write and provide evidence that supports your topic. End by Editing • Edit your work keenly to eliminate any errors and to ensure the flow, as well as structure, are perfect. • Also, ensure to support your main argument using your citations.

Thesis writing doesn’t happen overnight. It is a long process. It even does not start with a ‘thesis’. It is actually a project that you start and the first step is to have a plan ready. This planning or research proposal is your plan for your project based on the literature you read as well as your own interest. Then comes the empirical part in which you collect your data in whatever means you have devised in your proposal. Sometimes this means of data collection changes based on the context & circumstances you are in. Now you have your data, but that is usually too big to be included in the thesis as a whole. So comes the third step of data analysis. Through data analysis, you are able to be specific & succinct in presenting your project. You will choose what you want & what your data tells you. The fourth step then is the ‘thesis wrtiting’ which is really a continuation of your proposal, data collection, data analysis & data presentation.
